dt: {bc}hanging straight and limp without spring or curl

pt: {sc}lean{/sc} {sc}spare{/sc} {sc}lank{/sc} {sc}lanky{/sc} {sc}gaunt{/sc} {sc}rawboned{/sc} {sc}scrawny{/sc} {sc}skinny{/sc} mean thin because of an absence of excess flesh. {sc}lean{/sc} stresses lack of fat and of curving contours.
{sc}spare{/sc} suggests leanness from abstemious living or constant exercise.
{sc}lank{/sc} implies tallness as well as leanness.
{sc}lanky{/sc} suggests awkwardness and loose-jointedness as well as thinness.

pt.t: a {it}lanky{/it} youth, all arms and legs

pt: {sc}gaunt{/sc} implies marked thinness or emaciation as from overwork or suffering.
{sc}rawboned{/sc} suggests a large ungainly build without implying undernourishment.
{sc}scrawny{/sc} and {sc}skinny{/sc} imply an extreme leanness that suggests deficient strength and vitality.

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}hlanc{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}hlanca{/it} loin
shortdef: not well filled out : slender, thin
insufficient in quantity, degree, or extent
hanging straight and limp without spring or curl
